title: Understanding Hysteroscopy
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: A hysteroscopy is a simple procedure that allows a doctor to look inside your uterus (womb) using a thin telescope-like camera called a hysteroscope. It can be **diagnostic** (to diagnose problems) or **operative** (to treat problems).

content.description: 5-10 minutes for diagnosis, up to 30 if treatment is done

content.title: Why Hysteroscopy?
content.description: Commonly offered for abnormal bleeding or fertility issues. Safe way to find and treat common womb problems.

items: Difficulty getting pregnant or repeated miscarriages

content.title: Before Scheduling
content.description: Before scheduling, you'll have a consultation to discuss medical history, symptoms, and whether the procedure is appropriate.

steps: Pregnancy Test — may be asked to take one a week before
Use Contraception — between test and procedure (can't be done during pregnancy)
Pre-treatment Medicine — if having fibroids removed, may be given medicine to shrink them

content.title: Individual Instructions
content.description: Your healthcare team will give specific instructions based on your individual case.

content.value: A hysteroscopy is usually done as an outpatient procedure, meaning you can go home the same day.

items.title: No Anaesthetic
items.content: Often done without anaesthetic — many women tolerate it well.

items.title: Local Anaesthetic
items.content: Numbs the area around your cervix to reduce discomfort.

items.title: General Anaesthetic
items.content: If you prefer to be asleep during the procedure, this option is available.

steps: Positioning — lie on a couch with your legs supported
A speculum may be used to hold your vagina open
The hysteroscope is passed into the womb through the vagina and cervix
Fluid is gently pumped to expand the womb for a clearer view
A camera sends pictures to a monitor for the doctor to see

content.title: What to Expect
content.description: You may feel cramping similar to period pain, but it should not be painful.

items.title: Spotting
items.description: Light bleeding for a few days

items.title: Return to Normal
items.description: Most return to normal next day

items.text: Rest if you had a general anaesthetic
Avoid sex for about a week

content.title: Next Steps
content.description: Your doctor will discuss results and next steps before you leave.

items.title: Severe Abdominal Pain
items.description: Pain that doesn't improve with painkillers

content.title: Important Warning
content.description: These symptoms may be signs of infection (which are rare). Don't hesitate to contact your healthcare provider.
